(see item 132) |Rank=B |Title=Knowing the imaging semiology of chronic hydrocephalus in adults |Description=None |Heading=Additional examinations |Contributors= |Order=16}} Chronic adult hydrocephalus '''([[Discovery of a brain abnormality on medical imaging examination SD-226|discovery of a brain abnormality on medical imaging examination]])''' : - Abnormalities visible on brain scan or MRI. - Tetraventricular dilatation. - Absence of mass effect as opposed to obstructive hydrocephalus linked to the presence of an identified obstacle to CSF flow. - Suffusion of fluid into the periventricular parenchyma (''transependymal resorption'') leading to radiological abnormalities of the periventricular white matter (hypodensity on CT or T2-weighted hypersignal on MRI).

question.title: What is a characteristic of chronic adult hydrocephalus?
question.description: A brain abnormality visible on medical imaging examination

option_a.title: Presence of a mass effect
option_a.description: Linked to the presence of an identified obstacle to CSF flow

option_b.title: Absence of periventricular parenchyma
option_b.description: Suffusion of fluid into the periventricular parenchyma

option_c.title: Tetraventricular dilatation
option_c.description: Visible on brain scan or MRI

option_d.title: Obstructive hydrocephalus
option_d.description: Linked to the presence of an identified obstacle to CSF flow
